author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Random Q, does it make sense for nodes to randomly request each other blocks to ensure those nodes still have those blocks available?

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Penalty for no response is disconnect or blacklist

author: ajsutton
content: Not really no. You're just wasting your own bandwidth requesting stuff you don't need and there's not really anything stopping the remote node from just proxying your request onto another node so they can appear to have the block even though they didn't store it.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
Thanks for response. Bandwidth makes sense.
Proxying might be acceptable? Idk. You still atleast have a guarantee that the node youre connected to is able to source the blocks from somewhere (versus a situation where none of your peers even know how to get old blocks). Also the qeuried node's reputation is at stake, if it fails to get response from the third node within some period of time.

author: ajsutton
content: It's not the end of the world to not respond in time to some requests.  And the penalty for one peer disconnecting you isn't really much of a deterrent.  So you wind up with peers having to query random blocks from large numbers of their peers quite often.    Plus I'd probably just proxy the request back to the original node. üôÇ

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Bandwidth will be small I guess? Like for every 100 new blocks queried, query one old block

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: new as in to stay in sync

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Original node can refuse to answer because it is a test, unless you manage to ask the original node through a different node connected to it

author: ajsutton
content: Yeah but now your upping the complexity which needs careful thought to avoid introducing other potential bugs or security issues.

author: ajsutton
content: It‚Äôs probably doable to have data availability sampling but it‚Äôs not a simple thing to design well. And if you‚Äôre going to that effort it may be better to separate historic block storage from nodes tracking chain head anyway.

author: pietjepuk
content: <@!517636750940569600> I'd say you're not entirely certain there is another chain with even more PoW. If you have been on a "correct" chain for a while, you know more and more certain that you're likely to be correct. But indeed this one of the advantages of PoW. You still need to trust the software you run though, what forks you accept (i.e. what rules others are following), and it only works if you're the largest in your hashing algorithm hardware class (e.g. Bitcoin or Ethereum with ASICs and GPUs respectively for now, but there are no guarantees in life)

author: pietjepuk
content: As far as PoS is concerned, and the long/short range forks, see e.g. this (very old for cryptocurrency terms) post https://blog.ethereum.org/2014/11/25/proof-stake-learned-love-weak-subjectivity/
